> 1. We separate the test cases in an own package. Is that best 
> practice?

It's really up to you to decide.  I always have my tests in the same package and
happily survived this situation until now.

In fact I don't understand why someone would want to set hurdles by having a new
package for the tests.  Testing should not be a challenge (although it sometimes
is) so keep your options open and place your tests in the same package.  If you
never need to test your protected methods, fine.  But if you suddendly have to,
you still have the option to easily do so.

And even if your tests are in the same package, you don't have to test the
protected methods.

> 2. When doing this, some methods with default (package) visiblilty 
> cannot be accessed. But when using the Reflection API, this methods 
> can be accessed. Is it okay to use the reflection? Or is it bad 
> style?

See: just because you ('you' is general, not 'you' in particular) wanted to
write the cleanest tests of all and have a different package for them, you're
now messing with the Reflection API for writing a simple test.

There's a lot of situations where you want to test protected methods (like when
you write abstract classes that are meant to be published as part of an API) so
keep your options open.

I would say that the Reflection API should be only used when everything else has
failed.

> 3. What about testing private methods? It is normally not possible 
> if the test is in an own class. But again I can use the reflection 
> to acess private methods. Should I do that?

search the archive.  You'll have plenty of threads about it.  I never had to
directly test private methods, but if you have a large code base with no tests
at all, it can be your only option.

If you want to test private methods, don't reinvent the wheel and use the
PrivateAccessor class of the (you guessed it right!) JUnit-addons package.
